Universal Library for Android

UL for Android is a software API used to communicate with supported Measurement Computing DAQ devices over the Android 3.1 platform (API level 12) and later.

See:
          Description

Packages
com.mcc.ul  

 

UL for Android is a software API used to communicate with supported Measurement Computing DAQ devices over the Android 3.1 platform (API level 12) and later.

Before you begin, it is important to understand the classes that you need to work with. The following table describes the most important Universal Library APIs in the com.mcc.ul package.

ClassDescription
DaqDeviceManagerAllows you to detect and create DAQ devices.
DaqDeviceRepresents a DAQ device, and contains methods to access its I/O subsystems and to identify information and configurations.
AiDeviceRepresents an analog input subsystem on a DAQ Device, and contains analog input methods such as aIn() and aInScan(). This class also contains methods to access AI subsystem information and configuration.
AoDeviceRepresents an analog output subsystem on a DAQ Device, and contains analog output methods such as aOut() and aOutScan(). This class also contains methods to access AO subsystem information and configuration.
DioDeviceRepresents a digital I/O subsystem on a DAQ Device, and contains digital I/O methods such as dIn() and dOut(). This class also contains methods to access DIO subsystem information and configuration.
CioDeviceRepresents a counter I/O subsystem on a DAQ Device, and contains counter I/O methods such as cIn() and cClear() This class also contains methods to access CIO subsystem information and configuration.
TmrDeviceRepresents a timer I/O subsystem on a DAQ Device, and contains timer I/O methods such as tmrOutStart() and tmrOutStop(). This class also contains methods to access Tmr subsystem information and configuration.

Android Manifest Requirements

The following list describes what you need to add to your application's manifest file before working with the Universal Libary APIs:

In order to detect and access Bluetooth DAQ devices, you must declare the BLUETOOTH and BLUETOOTH_ADMIN permissions in your application manifest file. Be sure to include the following:

<manifest ...>
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.BLUETOOTH" />
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.BLUETOOTH_ADMIN" />
...
</manifest>

In order to detect and access Ethernet DAQ devices, you must declare the INTERNET and ACCESS_WIFI_STATE permissions in your application manifest file. Be sure to include the following:

<manifest ...>
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.INTERNET" />
<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.ACCESS_WIFI_STATE" />
...
</manifest>

Detecting and creating DAQ devices

In order to detect all of the DAQ devices currently paired with or attached to an android system, use the getDaqDeviceInventory() method. This method returns device descriptors for all of the DAQ devices that are currently paired with or attached to an android system.

DaqDeviceManager mDaqDeviceManager = new DaqDeviceManager(...);

// Find available DAQ devices
ArrayList<DaqDeviceDescriptor> daqDevInventory = mDaqDeviceManager.getDaqDeviceInventory();

if(daqDevInventory.size() > 0)

DaqDevice mDaqDevice = mDaqDeviceManager.createDaqDevice(daqDevInventory[0]);

Obtaining permission to communicate with a device

This step is only required for USB devices. Before communicating with a USB DAQ device, an application must have permission from the users to connect to the device.

To obtain a permission, first implement the onDaqDevicePermission() method of the DaqDeviceConnectionPermissionListener interface. This method is invoked when you call requestConnectionPermission(). The call to requestConnectionPermission() displays a dialog that prompts for permission to connect to the device. The following sample code shows how to request connection permission:

mDaqDevice.requestConnectionPermission(mDeviceConnectionPermissionListener);

public DaqDeviceConnectionPermissionListener mDeviceConnectionPermissionListener = new
DaqDeviceConnectionPermissionListener() {
public void onDaqDevicePermission(DaqDeviceDescriptor daqDeviceDescriptor, boolean permissionGranted) {
if(permissionGranted) {
try {
//Establish a connection with the DAQ device
mDaqDevice.connect();

} catch (Exception e) {
  ...
 }
}
}
};

Connecting to a DAQ device

Call the connect() method to establish a connection to a physical DAQ device.

mDaqDevice.connect();

Determining device capabilities

Call the methods in the "Info" class for each subsystem to determine the capabilities of the subsystem.

For example, to determine the capabilities of an AI subsystem on a DAQ device, call the methods in the AiInfo class. To determine the capabilities of a digital I/O subsystem, call the methods in the DioInfo class, and so on.

The code below shows you how to retrieve the maximum sample rate of an AI subsystem on a DAQ device:

//Create an instance of the AiInfo class

mAiInfo = mDaqDevice.getAiDev.getInfo();


//Get the max sample rate in S/s per channel

mAiInfo.getMaxScanRate();

Note: Most information methods can be used with virtual devices and with physical devices without establishing a connection to the device.

Retrieving and setting device configurations

Call the methods in the "Config" class for each subsystem to get or set the configuration of the subsystem.

For example, to configure an AI subsystem on a DAQ device, call the methods in the AiConfig class. To configure a digital I/O subsystem, call the methods in the DioConfig class, and so on.

The code below shows you how to retrieve the channel type of an AI channel:

//Create an instance of the AiConfig class

mAiConfig = mDaqDevice.getAiDev.getConfig();


//Create an instance of the AiChanConfig class

mAiChanConfig = mAiConfig.getAiChanConfig(chan);


//Get the AI channel type

mAiChanConfig.getChanType();


The code below shows you how to select a trigger source and configure its parameters:

//Create an instance of the AiDevice class

aiDevice = mDaqDevice.getAiDevice();


//Call the setTrigger() method

aiDevice.setTrigger(triggerType, triggerChannel, lowThreshold, highThreshold, thresholdUnit, retriggerCount);

Note: Configuration methods can be used only with physical devices and require establishing a connection to the device.

Reading and Writing data

In order to read data from a DAQ device or write data to a DAQ device, the corresponding subsystem on a DAQ device must be first obtained from the DAQ device. For example, to read data from an analog input channel you must retrieve the analog input subsystem from the DAQ device. The following sample code shows how to obtain an analog input subsystem and read data from channel zero of this subsystem:

AiDaqDevice mAiDevice = mDaqDevice.getAiDev();
mAiDevice.aIn(0, ChannelMode.SINGLE_ENDED, Range.BIP5VOLTS, AiUnit.VOLTS)

Example Projects

The UL for Android package includes example projects you can run to become familiar with the package. Refer to the UL for Android Example Projects for instructions on how to run each example.
